走过去，蓝鲸。地球历史上体型最大的动物出现了新的竞争者。

周三，科学家们描述了在秘鲁出土的一种早期鲸鱼的化石，这种鲸鱼名叫“Perucetus colossus”，生活在大约 38-4000 万年前的始新世时期。这种生物的体形有点像海牛，其质量可能超过了蓝鲸，长期以来，蓝鲸被认为是最古老的鲸鱼。有记录以来最重的动物。

研究人员估计，Perucetus（发音为 per-oo-SEE-tus）长约 66 英尺（20 米），重达 340 吨，这个重量超过了任何其他已知动物，包括今天的蓝鲸和最大的恐龙。它的学名意思是“巨大的秘鲁鲸鱼”。

“这种动物的主要特征无疑是极端的体重，这表明进化可以产生具有超出我们想象的特征的生物体，”意大利比萨大学的古生物学家乔瓦尼·比亚努奇（Giovanni Bianucci）说，他是发表在《自然》杂志上的这项研究的主要作者。自然杂志。

Perucetus 的最小质量估计为 85 吨，平均估计为 180 吨。已知最大的蓝鲸重约 190 吨，但比佩鲁塞图斯长 110 英尺（33.5 米）。阿根廷龙是一种长颈四足草食动物，生活在大约 9500 万年前的阿根廷，在 5 月份发表的一项研究中被列为最大的恐龙，估计重约 76 吨。

秘鲁鲸鱼的部分骨架是在秘鲁南部沿海沙漠中出土的，该地区富含鲸鱼化石，有 13 块椎骨、4 根肋骨和 1 块髋骨。这些骨头异常庞大，却极其致密、紧凑。这种被称为厚骨硬化症的特征在现存的鲸目动物（包括鲸鱼、海豚和鼠海豚）中不存在，但存在于海牛类（另一种海洋哺乳动物群体，包括海牛和儒艮）中。

据估计，仅其骨骼质量就在 5 至 8 吨之间，至少是蓝鲸的两倍。

“它肥胖、浮肿的身体可能更像海牛鱼，而不是任何现存的鲸鱼。在海牛鱼中，由于其巨大的体型和可能相似的生活方式，它可能让人想起斯特勒海牛，该海牛于 1741 年被发现，并被人类灭绝了一​​些。几年后，”比安努奇说道。

没有发现头骨或牙齿遗骸，这使得解释其饮食和生活方式变得更加困难。研究人员怀疑佩鲁塞特斯的生活就像海妖一样——不是活跃的捕食者，而是一种在浅海沿岸水域底部进食的动物。

“由于其沉重的骨骼，而且很可能是其非常庞大的身体，这种动物无疑是一个缓慢的游泳者。在我们目前的知识阶段，在我看来，这是一种和平的巨人，有点像一个超大号的动物。”海牛。它一定是一种非常令人印象深刻的动物，但也许并不那么可怕，”布鲁塞尔比利时皇家自然科学研究所的古生物学家奥利维尔·兰伯特说。

“也许它像海牛一样是草食性的，但这将是鲸目动物中唯一的例子。也许它像现存的灰鲸一样以沙底的小型软体动物和甲壳类动物为食。或者它可能是脊椎动物尸体的食腐动物，类似于一些现存的大型鲨鱼，”比安努奇说。

研究人员表示，秘鲁鲸不太可能像今天的须鲸（包括蓝鲸）一样是滤食性动物。

鲸鱼是在 5000 万年前从有蹄的陆生哺乳动物进化而来的，大小如中型狗。佩鲁塞图斯仍然拥有退化的后肢。

骨骼特征表明，秘鲁鲸与龙王鲸有亲缘关系，后者是另一种长度相似但体积较小的早期鲸鱼。然而，龙王鲸是一种活跃的捕食者，拥有流线型的身体、强大的下巴和大牙齿。

“Perucetus 表明鲸目动物至少两次发展出巨人症：在相对较近的时期，随着大型须鲸的进化，以及大约 4000 万年前，随着 Basilosaurus 亲戚的辐射，Perucetus 是其中最非凡的代表，”比安努奇说。

  • 比索兑美元非正式价值创历史新低
  • 年通货膨胀率飙升至45%
  • 老师说比索暴跌是“可怕的事情”

一项广受关注的追踪数据显示，周三，古巴比索在非正式市场上的交易价格为 230 兑 1 美元的历史新低，跌至一年前的一半，原因是消费者在通货膨胀和稀缺商品中挣扎。

国家认为通过独立新闻媒体 El Toque 广泛追踪的非正式汇率是非法的，但它一直无法将其关闭。该州正式将当地货币与美元挂钩，汇率为 120 比索，但可供兑换的货币很少。

“古巴货币的贬值反映了该岛生产性经济的缓慢崩溃，”汉堡德国全球和地区研究所的拉丁美洲专家伯特霍夫曼说。

古巴经济学家表示，比索暴跌反映出这个共产主义国家持续四年的危机不断加深，这场危机是由缺乏可兑换外币和生产下降造成的。

尽管当局主要将这场危机归咎于美国更严厉的制裁和新冠肺炎 (COVID-19) 大流行，但批评人士指出，市场化改革步伐缓慢。

经济部长亚历杭德罗·吉尔（Alejandro Gil）五月份表示，经济没有快速解决办法。

大多数古巴人的工资货币比索疲软，削弱了本已微不足道的工资的购买力，每月工资很少超过 5,000 比索，按当前汇率计算为 20 美元。随着比索暴跌，许多以美元进口的商品的当地成本也飙升。

货币贬值伴随着食品、药品和其他基本商品的短缺，只要有这些商品，就会出现排长队。

专家估计，古巴 1100 万人口中有 40% 完全依赖比索，无法获得美元。那些能够获得美元的人主要通过国外汇款或出售给游客来获得。

“美元不断上涨，”哈瓦那小学教师索尼娅·努涅斯说。 “我们必须自杀才能有钱买三美元，买一点洗涤剂，一点番茄酱，所以美元的涨幅是巨大的，这是可怕的事情。”

非正规利率的疲软类似于政府电子等价物的下降，居民必须使用电子等价物在国营商店购买商品，这些商店与比索商店相比库存相对充足。

虽然电子等价物是经国家批准发行的，但它们在街上的最终价值是由供需决定的。

经济部长吉尔上个月末表示，上半年国内生产总值增长了 1.8%，但仍比大流行前的水平低 8%。政府预计今年经济增长 3%。

吉尔表示，目前年通胀率约为 45%。去年价格上涨了 39%，许多经济学家表示这个数字低估了这一增长率，因为它没有充分考虑到不断增长的非正规市场。

台湾周四将关闭包括首都台北在内的台湾北部地区的市场和学校，因为在洪水和大风警告中，缓慢移动的台风卡农预计将掠过。

台风卡农被台湾气象局列为第二强台风，正缓慢向东北海岸移动，最大风速为每小时 209 公里（130 英里）。

周三早上，风暴袭击了日本热门旅游目的地冲绳岛的电线，导致超过 20 万户家庭停电，并导致一名男子死亡。

新北、基隆、宜兰和首都台北等北方城市将于周四关闭企业和学校。台湾股市和外汇市场也将关闭。

台湾中部山区的总降雨量预计将达到 0.6 米（2 英尺），而台北附近山区的降雨量预计将达到 0.3 米（1 英尺）。

气象官员表示，台风卡农正以 4 公里/小时（2.4 英里/小时）的速度向西移动，预计将于周四晚些时候绕过台湾北部海岸，然后在周五急剧转向东北。

近30个国内和国际航班已被取消，所有国内轮渡线路将于周四暂停。

国防部表示，中央政府已成立应急中心，数百名士兵在北方城市待命。

一些美国大型猪肉生产商花钱遵守加州法律，要求为某些农场动物提供更多生存空间，但他们对美国国会提出的推翻该州法律的立法态度冷淡。

猪肉行业贸易组织国家猪肉生产者委员会 (NPPC) 支持《结束农业贸易抑制 (EATS) 法案》，该法案由美国参议员罗杰·马歇尔 (Roger Marshall) 和众议员阿什利·辛森 (Ashley Hinson) 提出，该法案将限制各州监管农产品销售的能力在他们的境内。

立法者表示，他们的部分目标是推翻加州第 12 号提案，该提案禁止在该州销售居住条件不符合特定标准的动物的猪肉、小牛肉和鸡蛋。

但该国第五大猪肉加工商克莱门斯食品集团表示，它不支持 EATS 法案。荷美尔 (Hormel)、史密斯菲尔德 (Smithfield) 和泰森 (Tyson) 等其他大型生产商已公开表示，他们打算在 1 月 1 日生效时遵守加州法律。

自 2018 年以投票方式通过 12 号提案以来，NPPC 一直在反对该提案。5 月，该游说团体在美国最高法院提起的一项针对该法律的诉讼中败诉。

根据公开文件，该组织在 4 月至 6 月底之间花费了 78 万美元，就《EATS 法案》等问题进行游说。

动物福利组织表示，第 12 号提案是必要的，因为一些母猪和母鸡被关在笼子里，笼子太小，无法转身。

NPPC 首席执行官布莱恩·汉弗莱斯 (Bryan Humphreys) 在一封电子邮件中告诉路透社，该法律不会改善动物福利，会增加生猪生产者的成本，并可能导致更多“意识形态”国家限制。

不过，一些猪肉和鸡蛋公司已经投资使其部分生产符合 12 号提案的要求。

首席运营官克里斯·凯里 (Chris Carey) 表示，克莱门斯是 NPPC 的成员，已投入资金和时间升级设施并培训农民遵守法律。

“我们最终不认为 EATS 法案与动物福利的进步是一致的，”凯里说。

鸡蛋供应商 Eggs Unlimited 的全球贸易策略师 Brian Moscogiuri 表示，大约三分之一的鸡蛋行业也已经遵守规定。

荷美尔食品(HRL.N) 、史密斯菲尔德食品 (Smithfield Foods) 和泰森食品(TSN.N)没有回应有关 EATS 法案的问题。

加州大学圣克鲁斯分校经济学教授加林娜·黑尔表示，如果 EATS 法案通过，食品公司可能会失去在市场上区分其产品的能力并获得更高的价格。

哈佛法学院动物法律与政策项目的一份报告称，该法案还可能废除一千多个州和地方的公共卫生和安全法规，因为它的内容广泛。

“这个项目的每个方面都会受到一方或另一方的挑战，”该计划的执行董事克里斯·格林说。

放养猪

如果第 12 号提案成立，更多的生猪养殖可能会像小兰迪·赫顿 (Randy Hutton, Jr.) 在马里兰州切斯特敦 (该州东海岸的一个乡村小镇) 的农场那样。

小赫顿为尼曼牧场饲养生猪，尼曼牧场是肉类公司普渡农场的子公司，宣传其高动物福利标准。他在最近一次访问期间告诉路透社，他的怀孕母猪被饲养在围栏牧场中，而不是圈养生猪养殖中常见的妊娠栏，并且每头母猪至少有 35 平方英尺的活动空间。

尼曼牧场反对 EATS 法案。通讯副总裁 Kerri McClimen 表示，该公司的 750 家牧场主均遵守第 12 号提案。

小赫顿 (Hutton Jr.) 表示，他对在牧场饲养母猪很感兴趣，因为这比建造一个隔离谷仓要便宜，后者的成本可能高达 70 万美元。

“我们正在寻求更多的多元化，”他说。 “这是负担得起的。”

为绿色能源转型提炼稀土是困难的。问问 MP Materials 和 Lynas 就知道了。

中国以外的世界上最大的两家稀土公司正面临着将矿山中的岩石转化为全球经济中使用的磁铁的基石的挑战，从苹果(AAPL.O) iPhone 到特斯拉(TSLA.O) Model 3 再到洛克希德·马丁公司(LMT.N) F-35 战斗机。

北京上个月对战略金属镓和锗实施出口管制后，西方推动发展关键矿产的独立供应变得更加紧迫，引发了全球对中国下一步可能阻止稀土或加工技术出口的担忧。

最近，MP (MP.N) 、莱纳斯(LYC.AX)和其他公司在精炼自己的稀土方面遇到的困难凸显了世界其他国家在打破中国对清洁能源所需的 17 种关键金属的束缚方面面临的艰巨任务。能源转型，对十几位顾问、高管、投资者和行业分析师的采访显示。

技术复杂性、合作关系紧张和污染问题正在阻碍企业从中国夺取市场份额的能力，根据国际能源署的数据，中国控制着全球 87% 的稀土精炼能力。

如果项目继续陷入困境，如果没有北京的参与，一些经济体可能无法实现到 2050 年将碳排放量削减至零的目标，以尽量减少气候变化的影响。

据两位知情人士透露，澳大利亚莱纳斯公司与德克萨斯州合作伙伴在美国建设稀土精炼厂的计划已经失败。莱纳斯表示，它正在努力完成位于西澳大利亚州的一家稀土精炼厂，该精炼厂面临着障碍，并正在德克萨斯州其他地方建造自己的工厂。

MP 的目标是在 2020 年精炼自己的稀土金属，但由于 COVID-19 大流行和技术挑战而受阻，因此将其目标推迟到 2023 年底。更新可能会在周四公布，届时该公司预计将报告季度业绩。

去年年底，总部位于美国的 MP 表示，它正在其加州矿场附近调试炼油设备，作为复杂校准过程的一部分，但迄今为止尚未成功，这使得该公司的炼油业务以及几乎所有收入都依赖于中国。 MP 还在德克萨斯州建设一座磁铁工厂，为通用汽车(GM.N)供货，而这将需要加州的炼油设备投入运行。

MP 首席执行官兼最大股东吉姆·利廷斯基 (Jim Litinsky) 在 5 月份对投资者表示：“（稀土）调试过程非常艰苦，时断时续。”

MP的第二大股东是中国盛和资源（600392.SS） ，该公司拒绝在业绩公布前发表评论。

“稀土精炼过程可能非常挑剔，”亚利桑那大学采矿和地质工程系主任、与 MP 或其同行无关的克雷·卢克斯巴克 (Kray Luxbacker) 说。 “有这么多复杂的步骤。”

稀土磁铁将电力转化为运动，是电动汽车电机的重要组成部分。它们比传统磁铁更轻，并且可以承受更高的温度，部分原因在于它们独特的化学特性。

稀土精炼厂必须处理 17 种金属，具体取决于矿床的地质情况，每种金属的尺寸和原子量几乎相同， 使得分离变得复杂。这些稀土必须按照特定的顺序进行梳理，以防止 MP 及其同行挑选他们可能想要的特定元素。

例如，为了提取钕和镨来制造电动汽车磁体，MP 必须首先去除不太理想的镧和铈，这两种元素占其加州矿藏的 83% 左右，该过程依赖于酸、碱和其他化学物质的复杂混合物，是根据矿山的地质情况量身定制的。

虽然 MP 依靠中国的专业知识来重启其于 2017 年购买的矿山，但在定制炼油设备方面，这些专业知识的帮助不大。分析师表示，类似的问题可能会困扰其他六家打算在世界其他地方独立精炼的公司。

“中国多年来的情况是，他们在加工能力方面进行了大量而巧妙的投资，将（稀土）材料从矿山一直转化为磁铁，”该大学的冶金学教授艾伦·沃尔顿（Allan Walton）说。伯明翰大学。

经济调控

分析师表示，中国的炼油专业知识使该国能够在加工链的不同阶段设计稀土价格以发挥其优势，包括降低成品价格，以抑制外国竞争。

Adamas Intelligence 的矿物顾问 Ryan Castilloux 表示，稀土精炼“即使是那些正在开发磁铁能力的人也没有真正解决这一问题”。

卡斯蒂卢克斯补充说，通过战略性地重点关注使用磁铁的行业（这些磁铁是用中国精炼的稀土制成的，并且有意将利润率保持在较低水平），北京可以促进其蓬勃发展的电动汽车行业。

上个月，稀土价格跌至近三年来的最低水平，部分原因是中国供应增加，中国的模式得到了极大的缓解。中国还向使用其材料的磁体制造商提供 13% 的出口退税，进一步巩固了其主导地位。

北京多年来一直允许进口被称为稀土精矿的轻加工岩石用于精炼。分析师表示，该战略有助于确保价格能够激励其他国家挖掘新矿，但不会建造也能产生放射性废物的加工厂。

MP去年向中国运送了约43,000吨精矿用于精炼。监管文件显示，该公司还一直在亏本出售前任所有者在其位于加利福尼亚州的工厂留下的中国氟化物废物，该地区对该材料有严格的储存规定。

缅甸、 越南等国也将精矿运往中国进行精炼。

莱纳斯在马来西亚精炼在澳大利亚生产的精矿，但吉隆坡当局计划明年阻止进口，理由是担心莱纳斯工厂泄漏放射性废物，莱纳斯对这一指控提出异议。它的目标是今年晚些时候在澳大利亚开设一家替代加工厂。

该公司长期以来一直在美国向私营公司 Blue Line 出售稀土金属，以加工成特种材料。

根据获得的电子邮件，2019 年，两人同意在德克萨斯州圣安东尼奥附近建造炼油设施，并与特朗普政府官员讨论了他们的计划，即成为“中国以外世界上唯一的大规模分离（稀土元素）生产商”。路透社报道。

但两位消息人士告诉路透社，这项由五角大楼部分资助的努力已经失败。此前尚未报道过倒塌原因，目前无法立即确定。

蓝线公司推迟向莱纳斯发表评论。五角大楼表示无法立即发表评论。莱纳斯提到了过去的新闻稿，但拒绝进一步置评。与此同时，莱纳斯本周更新了利用五角大楼资助的 2.58 亿美元在德克萨斯州海岸建设其他炼油设施的计划。

据 Adamas Intelligence 称，在其他地方，瑞典、南非、澳大利亚和其他国家的项目旨在从矿山废料和副产品中提取稀土，这些项目可以成功满足全球 8% 的需求。

市场数据提供商 Benchmark Mineral Intelligence 估计，中国精炼了全球 89% 的钕和镨（电动汽车磁铁的关键金属），预计到 2028 年，这一主导地位将降至 75%。

Benchmark预测中国对镝精炼的全球控制力将从2023年的99%下降到2028年的94%。镝有助于在高温下保持磁化。

清洁技术

行业分析师表示，还需要关键的创新来打破中国对该行业的束缚，同时又不牺牲环境质量，因为人们担心当前工艺中的有毒废物会阻碍项目。

由于担心化学物质可能渗入饮用水，Leading Edge Materials (LEM.V)于 2016 年停止了开发瑞典诺拉卡尔稀土矿床的努力。该公司重新制定了矿山计划，使其更具可持续性，并于今年提交了新的环境申请。

特斯拉五月宣布计划生产不含稀土的电动汽车磁铁，理由是现有工艺存在“环境和健康风险”。

美国稀土公司(ARR.AX) 总裁梅丽莎·桑德森 (Melissa Sanderson)表示：“中国几十年前就做出了发展稀土加工能力的战略决定，尽管现有技术会对环境造成影响。”该公司正在开发多个美国稀土项目。

美国稀土公司正在与劳伦斯利弗莫尔实验室的美国政府科学家合作，开发可以处理稀土的细菌。私人控股的 Locus Mining 和 Aether Bio 也在分别研究使用生物表面活性剂和纳米技术的方法。

UCore Rare Metals (UCU.V) 、Mosaic (MOS.N)和私人持有的 USA Rare Earth 也在研究各种加工技术。

尽管如此，更清洁的解决方案距离生产还需要数年时间。

地缘政治咨询公司 Horizo​​n Advisory 的联合创始人内森·皮卡西克 (Nathan Picarsic) 表示：“如果您能够创新并将高效生产稀土的解决方案推向市场，那么您将拥有巨大的市场机会。”

民主党控制的参议院和共和党控制的众议院仍需要就这一概念的最终资金水平进行谈判，但两党就遏制中国的努力达成了普遍共识。

CL-20 计划

助手和熟悉该计划的人士告诉路透社，在国会最终批准之前，该法案将启动五角大楼的一项计划，试图使用中国湖化合物#20（也称为 CL-20）等化学物质来增加现有武器的射程。 。

一位高级国防官员表示，CL-20 是加利福尼亚州一家政府实验室于 20 世纪 80 年代开发的，是讨论最多的化合物之一。国会非常关注一项研究，例如 2021 年发表的一项研究，该研究称用 CL-20 重新为火箭提供动力以及其他改变可以将其射程延长约 20%。

Energetics技术中心的一篇论文称，新的高能材料使400磅炸弹“与当前1000磅炸弹具有相同的杀伤力”，并补充说中国“以工业规模制造CL-20并将其内置于武器系统中”。

诺斯罗普·格鲁曼公司(NOC.N)是美国 CL-20 的主要制造商之一。另一家主要火箭发动机制造商是 Aerojet Rocketdyne，该公司上周被 L3Harris Technologies (LHX.N)收购。

该办公室将成为陆军、海军和空军的协调机构，以消除机构的繁文缛节。

卡拉科表示，为美国库存武器重新提供动力或使用新的爆炸性化学物质的成本可能高达数十亿美元，并补充说，这一数字在很大程度上取决于哪些武器被重新提供动力，以及有多少武器被改装或购买。

非营利组织武装暴力行动执行董事伊恩·奥弗顿表示，调整已经致命的武器的竞赛并未取得进展。

“据说历史会重演，从某种意义上说，军备竞赛总是以糟糕的结局收场，”他说。 “更大、更致命的武器会让我们更安全吗？答案是响亮的：不会。在过去十年中，当爆炸性武器在人口稠密地区使用时，全球报告死亡或受伤的人中有 90% 是平民。”

众议院版本的年度国防法案要求五角大楼运行 CL-20 试点计划，更换三种现有武器中的炸药或推进剂。

众议院版本没有提及任何武器，但能源技术中心的鲍勃·卡维茨基表示，新化学品的候选者包括洛克希德·马丁公司制造的远程反舰导弹和增程空对地导弹。其他候选武器包括波音公司（BA.N）制造的“鱼叉”反舰导弹以及洛克希德和RTX （RTX.N）制造的“标枪”反坦克武器。

随着美国前总统准备周四在华盛顿法庭面临联邦指控，而佐治亚州检察官似乎准备在未来几周内提出自己的指控，追究唐纳德·特朗普试图推翻 2020 年大选刑事责任的努力正在升温。

2024 年共和党总统提名的领跑者特朗普于周二被指控四项罪名，包括合谋欺骗美国、阻碍官方程序以及合谋剥夺选民公平选举的权利。

在特别检察官杰克·史密斯提交的长达 45 页的起诉书中，检察官描述了一场规模庞大的多州阴谋，其基础是特朗普一再错误地声称民主党人乔·拜登的胜利受到广泛欺诈的损害。

根据起诉书， 特朗普无视顾问告诉他选举不存在欺诈，并帮助组织虚假的选举人名单，试图在他失去的州赢得选举人票。

检察官表示，特朗普及其盟友故意散布这些谎言，作为施压运动的一部分，试图说服州和联邦官员放弃选举结果，最终导致特朗普支持者暴徒于 2021 年 1 月 6 日冲击美国国会大厦。试图阻止国会认证拜登的胜利。

起诉书称：“尽管失败了，被告仍决心继续掌权。”

海牙特别法庭前首席检察官史密斯被美国司法部长梅里克·加兰任命为特别检察官。有时会任命特别检察官来处理政治敏感的调查，以使司法部免受偏见指控。

77 岁的特朗普是第一位面临刑事指控的美国前总统，今年已三次被起诉。六月，史密斯办公室在另一起案件中指控他在离开白宫后非法保留机密文件并阻碍取回这些文件。

特朗普在共和党提名中的主要竞争对手、佛罗里达州州长罗恩·德桑蒂斯拒绝透露起诉书中的具体细节，但发誓要结束“联邦政府的武器化”。

三分之二的情况不太好。周二，惠誉成为继 2011 年标准普尔之后第二家取消美国3A 信用评级的主要机构。

乌克兰国防部表示，敖德萨地区多瑙河伊兹梅尔港的一个粮仓遭到破坏：“乌克兰的粮食有潜力养活全世界数百万人，”该部在消息平台X（以前称为Twitter）上写道。

敖德萨地区州长奥莱·基佩尔在 Telegram 消息应用程序上发帖称，目前尚无人员伤亡报告。基珀发布了几张照片，显示消防人员试图扑灭河边一座破旧高层建筑的火灾。

总统弗拉基米尔·泽伦斯基在 Telegram 上表示：“不幸的是，造成了损失。”

乌克兰检察官办公室公布的照片显示，一名战争罪调查员站在一座被毁的建筑外，至少有两个筒仓受损，小麦翻滚而出。

该港口与北约成员国罗马尼亚隔河相望，自俄罗斯7月中旬重新对乌克兰黑海港口实施事实上的封锁以来，该港口一直是乌克兰粮食出口的主要替代路线。

周三袭击事件发生后，芝加哥小麦价格上涨 4%，交易商再次担心全球最大粮食出口国之一乌克兰退出市场，从而对全球供应造成打击。

自去年俄罗斯拒绝延长一项解除战时对乌克兰港口封锁的协议以来，俄罗斯在两周多的时间里无情地袭击了乌克兰的农业和港口基础设施。莫斯科要求为其本国的食品和化肥出口提供更好的条件，这些产品已经免受国际金融制裁。

乌克兰志愿军南方发言人谢尔希·布拉楚克（Serhiy Bratchuk）表示：“敌人……正试图摧毁乌克兰粮食，攻击工业和港口基础设施。不幸的是，有击中，筒仓被损坏，现场发生火灾。”乌克兰武装部队的一部分在视频声明中说道。

他说：“俄罗斯正试图将乌克兰排除在未来的粮食协议之外，最重要的是，从战略上将我国从全球粮食市场上取代。”

在俄罗斯退出黑海协议之前，乌克兰的多瑙河港口约占粮食出口的四分之一，此后成为主要出口路线，粮食装上驳船，运往罗马尼亚黑海康斯坦察港继续装运。

周日，乌克兰媒体报道称，几艘外国货船已从黑海直接抵达伊兹梅尔，这是自粮食协议到期以来的首次，这可能打破俄罗斯新恢复的封锁。

联合国警告称，由于俄罗斯决定放弃由联合国和土耳其斡旋的协议，世界上最贫穷的国家可能面临粮食危机和饥饿。

莫斯科表示，它将把前往乌克兰海港的船只视为潜在的军事目标。基辅曾表示希望船只无论如何都能返回，但到目前为止他们还没有这样做。

分析师周二表示，由于该协议在 7 月中旬破裂，乌克兰当月谷物出口量较 6 月下降了 40%。

俄罗斯无人机曾在 7 月下旬袭击过伊兹梅尔，摧毁了一个粮食仓库。

乌克兰官员表示，自退出粮食协议以来，莫斯科在九天的罢工中袭击了26个港口设施、五艘民用船只和18万吨粮食。莫斯科表示，此类袭击是对乌克兰袭击一座桥梁的报复，该桥梁是俄罗斯用来向乌克兰南部占领军提供补给的桥梁。

From building apartments for new employees to offering retired workers free canteen meals to share their expertise, Central Europe's arms manufacturers are scrambling for new ways to cope with the biggest boom since the end of the Cold War.

Facing some of the tightest labour markets in Europe, weapons makers in Poland and the Czech Republic are launching or expanding programs to recruit and train new workers after the Ukraine war drove a spike in demand for their productions.

Central Europe's arms industry has been churning out guns, shells and other military supplies at the fastest pace since the fall of the Berlin Wall as companies accelerate production to supply Ukraine and feed demand globally as countries boost defense spending.

Take Czech ammunition and artillery shell producer STV Group. It has agreed with the city closest to its biggest plant in Policka, some 200 kilometres (125 miles) southeast of Prague, to build company-financed apartments for new hires, the company's chairman David Hac told Reuters.

The company has also begun offering retired workers meals at the canteen so they can share knowledge of recently re-started lines producing Soviet-era ammunition for Ukraine, he added.

"This informal exchange of ideas has excellent and immediate effects on the efficiency of production processes, especially when you are restarting production of products that have been out of production for a long time," Hac said.

The Czech Republic and Poland boast among the lowest unemployment rates in the European Union at 2.7% for June, well below the EU average jobless figure of 5.9% for the same period, according to Eurostat data.

Jiri Hynek, president and executive director of the Defence and Security Industry Association (DSIA) of the Czech Republic, told Reuters a lack of workers could push production out of central Europe. With enough labor and materials, Czech companies could boost production by up to 20 percent, he estimated.

The association, which represents more than 160 companies, said exports accounted for around 90 percent of the industry's production of weapons and military-related supplies.

Of that, Hynek estimated that supplies of military equipment to Ukraine accounted for 40% of exports.

As demand grows, the need for younger workers with technical skills will only intensify for an industry that depends on innovation to keep growing, Hynek added.

"We have an ageing population, ageing researchers, developers, innovators, and technical and natural sciences (departments) producing an absolute lack of people to use," Hynek said. "We need growth but we have nowhere to take workers from."

KEY WEAPONS PIPELINE

Czech explosives maker Explosia - which employs around 600 workers and posted a record 1.2 billion crowns ($55 million) in revenue last year - told Reuters it is expanding cooperation with local universities and speeding automation to offset a lack of workers at the company, which is known for producing the plastic explosive Semtex.

Polish military technology company WB Group started hiring women last year on a larger scale on assembly lines previously comprising mostly male workers. The company - which employs more than 2,000 staff and generated 602 million zloty ($150 million) in revenue last year - produces unmanned drones and missile systems.

"With the increase in orders we had to change the production system," the company's spokesman told Reuters.

Central Europe represents an important pipeline for Ukraine's military. Of the 29 states that supplied major weapons in 2022, Poland and the Czech Republic accounted for more than 20 percent of the total Ukrainian arms imports by volume, according to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute.

The Czech government said that - including weapons supplied from its own stores - the country sent military supplies worth 40 billion Czech crowns ($1.84 billion) to Ukraine in the first 12 months of the war. That included 89 tanks, 226 armored vehicles, 38 howitzers along with air defense systems, helicopters, ammunition and rockets, it said.

The Czech defense ministry told Reuters, without providing specific details, that the strongest demand from Ukraine was now for large-calibre ammunition for Soviet-era weapons along with western standard artillery, rocket propelled grenades, and tank ammunition.

The government has also started discussions about employing some of the hundreds of thousands of Ukrainian refugees - most of whom are women and children - living in the country to help companies struggling to find workers, the defense ministry said.

PITCHING PATRIOTISM

Other sectors in Poland – emerging Europe's biggest economy – and the Czech Republic have struggled in recent years to find workers: a situation that has driven up labor costs and dampened growth.

But the issue is a new one for the arms industry, where the workforce shrank in the wake of the Communist era.

Between the mid-1980s and 2000, employment in Poland's arms industry fell by 76 percent, according data cited by the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute.

"Of course, you need raw materials and supplies but the lack of skilled workers is now the main problem hampering the expansion of production," Czech independent defense analyst Lukas Visingr told Reuters.

Poland's state-owned PGZ – which controls dozens of companies making supplies that include weapons, ammunition, armoured transporters and unmanned air systems – is targeting employees in a wide range of industries using social media ads, the group's head of human resources, Artur Zaborek, told Reuters.

The company - which employs more than 18,000 people - also plans a campaign next year aimed at convincing Poles employed in Scandinavian shipyards to return home to work on new contracts to build ships for Poland's navy using ads that highlight the opportunity to boost national defense and work closer to home, Zaborek said.

"The geopolitical situation has led to the largest armaments projects in history for the group, which means demand for skilled workers has increased dramatically," Zaborek said.

Asian stocks traded lower while US Treasury yields declined on Wednesday, after ratings agency Fitch unexpectedly downgraded the United States' top-tier sovereign credit rating.

MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares (.MIAP00000PUS) fell 0.5%. Japan's Nikkei (.N225) slid by 1.2%, while Australian shares (.AXJO) edged down 0.5%.

China's mainland benchmark (.SSEC) and Hong Kong's (.HSI) fell by 0.3% and 0.5%, respectively.

Asian stocks were also weighed by declines on Wall Street overnight. US stock futures, the S&P 500 e-minis , pointed 0.2% lower on Wednesday.

Fitch cut the United States by one notch to AA+ from AAA, citing fiscal deterioration, a decision announced after the Wall Street close on Tuesday.

US 10-year Treasury yields declined by about 2 basis points to 4.025% in Tokyo.

"Most of the Asia turmoil this morning and the Treasury yields move is triggered by the Fitch decision," said Manishi Raychaudhuri, head of Asia Pacific equity research at BNP Paribas.

"It's kind of a short-term knee-jerk reaction, so we will have to wait and watch for how this pans out."

Investors counterintuitively fled to the relatively safety of sovereign debt from riskier equity markets. Treasuries, whose yields fall when prices rise, were also bought when Standard & Poor's cut the US top "AAA" rating by one notch to "AA-plus" in 2011.

The US dollar moved lower against a basket of major currencies immediately after the announcement, but was up 0.1% as of the Asian morning.

While the investor reaction to the downgrade was relatively contained, it has injected some uncertainty into financial markets.

"This basically tells you is the US government's spending is a problem. It's an unsustainable budget situation because the economy can't even grow its way out of this problem going forward," said Steven Ricchiuto, US chief economist, Mizuho Securities. "Therefore, they're going to have to either tackle it or accept the consequences of potential further additional downgrades."

Looking beyond the Fitch downgrade, the main area of focus will still be central banks, corporate earnings and, in China specifically, stimulus prospects the geopolitical issues, he said.

The United States publishes fresh data on jobless claims and unemployment later this week.

  • Australian federal workers have world's strongest WFH rights
  • Employees globally want more WFH than their bosses - survey
  • Office attendance remains far below 2019 levels - JLL

Before COVID-19 sent one-third of the global workforce home, the Melbourne property surveyor that employs drone operator Nicholas Coomber called its 180-strong staff into the office every day at 9 am to hand out assignments.

Now that they work from home, the surveyors travel straight to the field as early as 7.30 am, enabling Coomber to pick up his children from daycare earlier than before the pandemic.

"If they were to say 'everyone back in the office', I would probably be asking for a raise," said Coomber, who still visits the office once or twice a week. "You get more family time. You can actually finish work at five, rather than finishing at five spending 45 minutes trying to get home."

As corporate leaders from JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon to Tesla and Twitter boss Elon Musk call for an end to pandemic-era remote work arrangements, unions in Australia are setting a precedent and fighting back, taking to court the country's biggest bank and wrangling with the federal government to demand WFH, as it is known, to become the norm.

"All the deep changes in the Australian labour market have come out of crises. When you have a jolt, you never return to the way the world was," said John Buchanan, head of the University of Sydney's Health and Work Research Network.

"We're always ahead of the pack in the English-speaking world, say compared to the UK, US, New Zealand."

Empowered by the lowest unemployment rate in half a century, staff at Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA.AX) took the A$170 billion ($114 billion) lender to the industrial tribunal to challenge a directive to work from the office half of the time.

In April, the CEO of Australia's third-largest bank, National Australia Bank (NAB.AX) , ordered 500 senior managers back to the office full-time. In July, NAB agreed to a union deal that gives all employees, including the 500 managers, the right to request WFH, with limits on grounds of refusal.

That same week, the public sector union struck a deal the which lets Australia's 120,000 federal employees request work-from-home an unlimited number of days.

By comparison, Canada's federal workers ended a two-week strike in May with a wages agreement that came without the WFH protections they wanted. And in the European Union, lawmakers are still negotiating updates to decades-old "telework" protections to fit a post-lockdown economy, where actual office attendance is down on 2019 levels anywhere from a fifth in Tokyo to more than half in New York, according to global real estate company Jones Lang Lasalle (JLL.N) .

"The genie's out of the bottle: working from home is something that is staying well beyond COVID and the pandemic," said Melissa Donnelly, the Community and Public Sector Union secretary who negotiated the Australian federal agreement.

"What was possible around working from home has absolutely been transformed," she added. "This is what this deal achieves. It will have a flow on effect across different industries."

CBA and NAB say that even before the union deals, their policies allowed flexible working arrangements, which were widely used.

'HISTORIC CONFRONTATION'

Though the number of remote-work days sought by employees differs between country and industry, the gap between employee WFH demands and their bosses' return-to-office orders is a global constant, said Mathias Dolls, deputy director of the ifo Center for Macroeconomics and Surveys in Hamburg which polled 35,000 workers and employers in 34 countries as part of a project with Stanford University.

Among employees with WFH experience, 19% wanted to return to the office full-time, the survey found. Workers wanted two days a week of WFH, double what bosses wanted, and "the gap is not shrinking," said Dolls. "I don't think we will see WFH levels going back to pre-pandemic levels."

Jim Stanford, director of the Centre for Future Work at the Australia Institute, a think tank, said individual union deals would not necessarily end the stalemate since employers would get more bargaining power if unemployment rose, a widely-expected by-product of rising interest rates.

"The overall weight of opinion among workers is strongly they'd like to keep doing it and I think an emerging majority of employers are thinking, no, they want people back to work," Stanford said.

"That sets the stage for a historic confrontation."

CHANGED WORKFORCE

The shift to remote work, from as little as 2% of Australian hours worked in 2019 to a standard of white-collar employment, has already disrupted the business model of office landlords who report declining building valuations amid concerns about reduced floorspace being rented by companies.

About one-sixth of Australian capital city office space is vacant, a multi-year high, industry data shows, as in-person attendance remains at least a third below pre-pandemic levels.

While WFH spells pain for investors in bricks and mortar , employees like drone operator Coomber can only see benefits: flexible work arrangements recently allowed him and his wife to keep working for two weeks when their children were too sick to attend childcare.

"It just helps get through life a little bit easier," he said.

A large number of prisoners held in makeshift detention centres in Russian-occupied southern Ukraine were tortured and sexually violated, a team of international experts said on Wednesday in a summary of their latest findings.

The Mobile Justice Team, established by the international humanitarian law firm Global Rights Compliance, has worked with Ukrainian war crimes prosecutors in the Kherson region since it was reclaimed in November after more than eight months under Russian control.

Ukrainian authorities are reviewing more than 97,000 reports of war crimes and have filed charges against 220 suspects in domestic courts. High-level perpetrators could be tried at the International Criminal Court (ICC) in The Hague, which has already sought the arrest of Russian President Vladimir Putin.

The Kremlin has consistently denied allegations of war crimes in Ukraine by forces taking part in a "special military operation" it says was launched to "de-Nazify" its neighbour and protect Russia.

The Mobile Justice Team's latest report, funded by Britain, the European Union and the United States, analysed 320 cases and witness accounts at 35 locations in the Kherson region.

Of the victims' accounts reviewed "43% explicitly mentioned practices of torture in the detention centres, citing sexual violence as a common tactic imposed on them by Russian guards", a statement said.

In June, Ukrainian prosecutors brought their first case over the alleged deportation of dozens of orphans from Kherson, charging a Russian politician and two suspected Ukrainian collaborators with war crimes. They provided no immediate comment to the latest findings on torture.

WATERBOARDING, BEATINGS

Reuters reported in January on the scale of alleged torture in Kherson. Ukrainian authorities said at the time that around 200 people had allegedly been illegally held. Survivors told Reuters about tactics, including electric shocks and suffocation.

At the time, the Kremlin and Russia's defence ministry did not respond to Reuters' questions, including about alleged torture and unlawful detentions.

"The true scale of Russia's war crimes remains unknown," Anna Mykytenko, senior legal adviser at Global Rights Compliance, said of the latest findings on torture.

"But what we can say for certain is that the psychological consequences of these cruel crimes on Ukrainian people will be engrained in their minds for years to come."

At least 36 victims interviewed by prosecutors mentioned the use of electrocution during interrogations, often genital electrocution, as well as threats of genital mutilation. One victim was forced to witness the rape of another detainee, the report said.

Detainees most likely to undergo torture were military personnel, it found, but also law enforcement, volunteers, activists, community leaders, medical workers and teachers. The torture techniques most commonly used were suffocation, waterboarding, severe beatings and threats of rape, it found.

Reuters was unable to verify the allegations.

All told, the evidence from liberated detention centres "suggests that Putin's plan to extinguish Ukrainian identity includes a range of crimes evocative of genocide", said British Barrister Wayne Jordash, who headed the team.

"This will rally his supporters to his talking points - about how the establishment and the 'deep state' are against him and against them," Stu Rothenberg, a non-partisan political analyst, said before the indictment was handed down.

Trump, the former president, has made the indictments a central plank of his campaign platform, portraying himself as the target of a biased justice system, the first former president in US history to face criminal charges.

Minutes before the indictment was announced, Trump called it "fake" on his Truth Social media platform.

A Trump campaign statement later said: "President Trump has always followed the law and the Constitution, with advice from many highly accomplished attorneys." The statement likened his indictments this year to "Nazi Germany in the 1930s."

The indictments are piling up - three so far this year. And so are the court dates.

His New York state criminal trial involving a hush money payment to a porn star is due to start on March 25, 2024, and his Florida trial in a federal classified documents case is scheduled to begin on May 20.

Both would take place just months before the November election. So might a third trial in this latest case centered on his failed bid to overturn his 2020 election defeat to Democrat Joe Biden. Trump must appear in court on Thursday in this case.

策略师表示，虽然这些起诉书可以帮助特朗普巩固其基本盘的支持并赢得共和党提名，但他在明年的大选中利用这些起诉书的能力可能会更加有限，届时他将不得不赢得更多持怀疑态度的温和派共和党人和独立人士。

In a July Reuters/Ipsos poll, 37% of independents said the criminal cases against Trump made them less likely to vote for him for president, compared to 8% who said they were more likely to do so.

Underscoring the potential closeness of the November 2024 general election, the latest Reuters/Ipsos poll shows Biden leading Trump 37% to 35% in a hypothetical match-up, with the remaining 28% saying they were not sure of their choice or whether they would vote for someone else or no one at all.

The strategists said Trump was likely to stick to his campaign playbook for now and use the latest indictment to reinforce his central argument that - despite being a former president - he is an outsider running to protect his supporters from a runaway Justice Department rigged against Republicans.

"They're not indicting me, they're indicting you. I just happen to be standing in their way," Trump declared at a campaign rally in Pennsylvania on July 29.

Trump's rivals for the nomination have so far largely stayed silent about his first two indictments, although that could change given this latest one alleges he sought to overturn an election in an assault on a bastion of American democracy.

"If the past pattern holds, with conservative media and Republicans sort of not going after Trump on it, this isn't going to make a significant difference with the Republican 2024 primary," said Chris Jackson, a public opinion researcher at polling firm Ipsos, which conducts polls for Reuters and other media organizations.

Shortly before the hush-money indictment in March, Trump's share of party support stood at 44%, 15 percentage points above his closest rival, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, who had 29% support. After he was indicted in the hush money case, his support rose to 49%, while DeSantis slipped to 23%.

Since then that dynamic has held. A second batch of criminal charges in June accusing Trump of willful retention and improper sharing of national defense information had little lasting impact on Trump's polling numbers, Jackson said.

The relentless media focus on Trump and the indictments also drowns out his rivals as they seek a breakthrough moment in the Republican primary battle, a race Trump has dominated for months, said John Feehery, a Republican strategist.

"(DeSantis) is not going to be able to get a word in edgewise," Feehery said.

Like Jackson at Ipsos, Rothenberg predicts a close general election in November 2024, no matter who the Republicans nominate to face off against Biden, the likely Democratic opponent.

But if it is Trump, Rothenberg said he is in danger of losing enough independents and moderates to lose the election, in part because of the indictments.

"There can be a point at which various groups of people along the way say, 'I've just had it. I'm tired of this. I'm tired of this fighting. I'm tired of Donald Trump,'" Rothenberg said.

在出海的第十天，四名尼日利亚偷渡者在一艘货船舵上方的狭小空间里横渡大西洋，食物和饮料都耗尽了。

根据他们的说法，他们通过饮用下方几米处的海水又存活了四天，然后在东南部维多利亚港被巴西联邦警察救起。

他们跨越约 5,600 公里（3,500 英里）海洋的非凡、玩命的旅程突显了一些移民为了追求更好的生活而准备冒的风险。

“这对我来说是一次可怕的经历，”四名尼日利亚人之一、38 岁的感谢上帝·奥佩米波·马修·耶耶 (Thankgod Opemipo Matthew Yeye) 在圣保罗教堂避难所接受采访时说道。 “在船上并不容易。我浑身发抖，很害怕。但我在这里。”

他们因获救而感到的欣慰很快就变成了惊讶。

这四人表示，他们原本希望到达欧洲，但当得知他们实际上已经降落在大西洋彼岸的巴西时，他们感到震惊。其中两名男子已应要求返回尼日利亚，而耶耶和来自巴耶尔萨州的 35 岁罗曼·埃比梅内·星期五已在巴西申请庇护。

“我祈祷巴西政府怜悯我，”周五说。他此前曾试图乘船逃离尼日利亚，但被当地当局逮捕。

两人都表示， 经济困难、 政治不稳定和犯罪行为让他们别无选择，只能放弃祖国尼日利亚。这个非洲人口最多的国家长期存在暴力和贫困问题，绑架事件也十分猖獗。

耶耶是拉各斯州的五旬节派牧师，他说，他的花生和棕榈油农场今年被洪水摧毁，导致他和家人无家可归。他希望他们现在可以去巴西与他会合。

星期五说，他的巴西之旅于6月27日开始，当时一位渔民朋友把他划到停泊在拉各斯的悬挂利比里亚国旗的“Ken Wave”号船尾，然后让他掌舵。令他惊讶的是，他发现三个人已经在那里等待船出发。星期五说他很害怕。他从未见过他的新船友，担心他们随时可能把他扔进海里。

星期五说，当船开始移动时，这四名男子尽一切努力不被船员发现，他们还担心船员可能会为他们提供一个水坟墓。

“也许如果他们抓住你，他们会把你扔进水里，”他说。 “所以我们教会自己永远不要发出声音。”

在距大西洋仅几步之遥的地方待上两周是很危险的。

星期五说，为了防止自己落入水中，这些人在船舵周围架起了一张网，并用绳子将自己绑在上面。当他低头一看时，他说他可以看到“像鲸鱼和鲨鱼这样的大鱼”。由于环境拥挤，发动机噪音大，睡眠很少而且很危险。 “当我们获救时，我非常高兴，”他说。

圣保罗庇护所的牧师保罗·帕里塞神父说，他还遇到过其他偷渡者的案例，但从未见过如此危险的案例。他说，他们的旅程证明了人们将不遗余力地寻找新的开始。 “人们做了难以想象且极其危险的事情。”
